children.subject: Yes, thanks!
Thanks
Common sense has finally prevailed. Thanks for that!
This will really help future classes.
Thank you.
Thank you very much!
Thanks Professor.
I will keep this in mind when I restart this class at a later date, since I feel I was forced to drop by the ambiguity of this assignment.   Thanks...  Good luck everyone.
Thank you!!
I'd prefer you looked into mine and gave partial credit out of pity.
I believe that they will be adjusting the autograder to accept the results in either model (sorted or unsorted).

Good deal. BTW, Conor, I think I speak for everyone when I ask: when do you sleep???

Thanks for all your input and advice!

Sleep is for the weak. This is CS baby...we don't sleep, we drink more caffeine and eat carb loaded junk food and code on! 

Plus when you're old you have to get up more at night anyway so might as well be productive. <edited> I'm referring to myself...not saying Conor is old. :-)
I just looked through all of those and everything I've seen still says sorting is nice and appreciated, but not required.

What about people who, based on the information in Piazza, sorted the nodes in the results, submitted before @502 came out, and didn't get a chance to get on Piazza yesterday? I submitted my Project 3 early Sunday morning about 1am eastern, after having read through all the Piazza messages, and came to the conclusion that I should sort the nodes alphabetically. I did not check Piazza during the day on Sunday, so I didn't see @502 to know that we should not sort. It would be an easy change for me to remove that sorting, but the deadline to do so has passed. What are my options?
The answer is simple: the TAs are virtual ;). Just kidding.

I think this is because the only TA we had originally was Sean and that when the others came onboard (seemed to be delays due to hiring paperwork) we were already behind in how much grading needed to be done.

That and, in many cases, TAs are restricted in the number of hours they can put in (though this doesn't seem to affect Sean!).

Speculation on that could follow that Sean isn't grading so much either tho. Load balancing. Unknown but to be honest, I haven't had any issues to date with time frames or getting help. Other classes I've taken generally have more TAs involved in Piazza but during summer if you want turn around on grading, allocations have to focus there. A cake and eating it too issue.
Agreed.... even if you did call me an old man.... :-)
Yeah...glass houses. I have kids older than some of the people in this class (and probably most of the TAs).
I have had other TAs respond to private posts to instructors. Perhaps Sean is the public facing TA and the others are private?
Perhaps "Sean" isn't real... perhaps he's a Virtual TA who's identity is shared by multiple "real" TAs...

I am just going to throw this out there and hope I don't offend anyone: is there a reason we only see 1 TA (Sean) and the instructor posting on Piazza? Do the other TAs participate in Piazza? If not, may I humbly suggest they start? 

When I took IOS (CS8803-2) last term, there were on average 3+ TAs (plus the instructor) reading/answering posts regularly. Part of the issue here may be there are just two of you (Dave and Sean) monitoring/answering ~350 students on this forum...

Same here.  I sorted my messages in alphabetical order, ex.Node B would output AB1 instead of BA1.  Will that matter for grading?  

Also, and this is just my opinion here not trying to criticize but I felt like this hw was a little bit much for only having 1 week to complete the assignment.

If you sort the nodes before you process them, the number of steps that it takes to complete the mappings and stabilize the network can be different (sometimes more, sometimes less, sometimes just the same).

They have stated that they are not going to grade intermediate results, so this should not matter (though they may check to verify that you are generating intermediate results).

Sorting the output horizontally or vertically is not required but will be accepted.
cool, thanks Conor.
ugh now im secod guessing myself, what are "some of the particulars that affect the intermediate results in small ways"?

I would like to post this in as positive a light as possible, and offer it as constructive criticism.

The following items should be improved for the next offering of this course:

-the instructions on this assignment were less than 100% clear

-Weds 3PM office hours is going to limit participation, so little chance the correct questions get asked/answered

-It seems that conflicting instructions for this assignment on Piazza were  clarified/corrected only a few hours before the assignment was due, and after many assignments had been submitted

I understand that teaching and TAing these courses must be challenging.

Clarifying the scope of the assignment at the last minute, and then deciding on the grading criteria after the assignment has been submitted will lead to wasted hours by the students working on the assignment.

Suggestions as far as clarifying the instructions -

It might be beneficial to to specifically comment each function which the student may change (and then which one's they should not change).  I believe the only way to sort the nodes was to change code in what might be considered more of a driver routine than in code that was supposed to simulate what an individual node would do, because the nodes don't have knowledge of the global dv space. 

The initial setup of self aware only vs. aware of self + neighbors was a question mainly because self.neighbor.  I don't have the code in front of me right now, but was self.neighbor actually needed to solve the problem?  If not - perhaps that field could be dropped from the data structure. 

And of course - the pump priming could have specifically spelled only to send the self aware message, but I think that falls out from the above. 

Probably the most helpful thing for me was when David or Sean posted a couple of answers - I figured that my output better look like that, so I changed things from self+neighbor to self aware.

history.content:
Due to the large number of people who only became aware at the last minute of some of the particulars that affect the intermediate results in small ways, we have decided that we will only grade based on the final result of your DV projects.  (We may check to make sure that you have intermediate results, i.e., that you didn't just skip directly to the final answer, but we won't really look at what they say.)

We think this is a better solution than either penalizing you for pedantic details or giving you extra time in order to fix pedantic details when we really should be moving on with the class. (If this pertained to the learning objectives for the project, that may be different. However, it does not - it really has to do with the auto-grade-ability of it, and specifically of the intermediate results - so the solution is we'll just grade the final results only.)

We're also going to look at improving the assignment description and starter code for future semesters (including providing log examples in the description itself), and we'll also give example output from the beginning on future assignments, if it is relevant for those assignments.

#pin
history.subject: Announcement: Project 3 Intermediate Results
